verse:
बर्हापीडं नटवरवपुः कर्णयोः कर्णिकारं बिभ्रद् वासः कनककपिशं वैजयन्तीं च मालाम् ।
रन्ध्रान् वेणोरधरसुधया पूरयन्गोपवृन्दैर्वृन्दारण्यं स्वपदरमणं प्राविशद् गीतकीर्तिः ॥

terms.āpīḍam: as the decoration of His head
terms.karṇikāram: a particular kind of blue lotuslike flower
terms.sva-pada: because of the marks of His lotus feet

vedabase.translation: Wearing a peacock-feather ornament upon His head, blue karṇikāra flowers on His ears, a yellow garment as brilliant as gold, and the Vaijayantī garland, Lord Kṛṣṇa exhibited His transcendental form as the greatest of dancers as He entered the forest of Vṛndāvana, beautifying it with the marks of His footprints. He filled the holes of His flute with the nectar of His lips, and the cowherd boys sang His glories.
vedabase.purport: The gopīs remembered all the transcendental qualities of Kṛṣṇa mentioned in this verse. Kṛṣṇa’s artful way of dressing and the beautiful blue flowers placed over His ears excited the gopīs’ romantic desires, and as He poured the nectar of His lips into His flute, they simply lost themselves in ecstatic love for Him.

terms.कर्णयोः कर्णिकारं: having earrings in the shape of lotus petals
terms.कनककपिशं: the one who wears an attire made of golden silk
terms.वैजयन्तीं च मालाम्: and a garland of Vaijayanti flowers
terms.वेणोरधरसुधया: with the nectar flowing from the flute
terms.गीतकीर्तिः: the fame of your divine songs

gpt.meaning: You, with your peacock feather adorned crown, the finest among dancers, Your lotus petal shaped earrings and clothing made of golden silk,

terms.karṇayoḥ karṇikāram bibhrat vāsaḥ `: ` karṇas wore a garland of karṇikāra
terms.kanaka kapiśam vaijayantīm ca mālām `: ` wore a garland of golden kapiśa and jasmine
terms.randhrān veṇoḥ adhara sudhayā āpūrayan `: ` filled the holes of his veṇu with nectar
terms.gopa-vṛndaiḥ vṛndā-araṇyam sva-pada rama: ` entered the forest of vṛndāvana, pleasing the cowherds with his sweet music

bard.meaning: overall meaning:The verse describes the beauty of gīta kīrti: her body was pressed against the naṭa's body, she wore a garland of karṇikāra, golden kapiśa, and jasmine, she filled the holes of her veṇu with nectar, and she entered the forest of vṛndāvana, pleasing the cowherds with her sweet music.
